normal.statement: Which quantity can be negative for one-dimensional motion along the x-axis?
In SI, the unit of average velocity is:
A particle moves from x = 2 m to x = -3 m. Its displacement is:
The slope of an x–t graph at any instant gives:
A car’s speedometer reads 36 km h^{-1}. Its speed in SI units is approximately:
Average speed equals average velocity when:
options: Motion is along a straight line without change of direction
normal.answer: Motion is along a straight line without change of direction

normal.statement: If velocity is constant, which statement is true?
Which graph indicates uniform velocity?
options: x–t is a straight line with constant slope
a–t is a straight line with nonzero value
normal.answer: x–t is a straight line with constant slope

normal.statement: Dimension of velocity is:
A body moves 4 m east and then 3 m west. The distance and displacement are:
Instantaneous acceleration is defined as:
options: Time rate of change of velocity at an instant
Rate of change of speed only
normal.answer: Time rate of change of velocity at an instant

normal.statement: Area under a v–t graph between two instants equals:
Which is true for uniformly accelerated straight-line motion?
options: x–t graph is a straight line
v–t graph is a straight line
normal.answer: v–t graph is a straight line

normal.statement: A particle has velocity 0 at t = 0 and constant acceleration a. Its position is given by:
A car moves with uniform speed of 15 m s^{-1}. In 4 s it travels:
If x = 5 + 2t (in m), the motion is:
Which quantity does an odometer measure directly?
For motion with constant acceleration a, the relation \(v^{2} - u^{2} = 2 a s\) holds. Here s is:
Which situation guarantees zero average velocity over a time interval?
A v–t graph is a horizontal line at v = 8 m s^{-1}. The motion is:
The SI unit of acceleration is:
If a particle’s x–t graph is horizontal, its velocity is:
A runner covers the first 100 m in 10 s and the next 100 m in 20 s on a straight track. Average speed for 200 m is:
Which measurement tool gives the most direct estimate of instantaneous velocity in a lab car-on-track setup?
If x = 4t^{2} (in m), instantaneous velocity at t = 3 s is:

moderate.statement: A particle moves with \(u = 5\,\text{m s}^{-1}\) and constant acceleration \(a = 2\,\text{m s}^{-2}\). Its velocity after 4 s is:
For motion with constant \(a\), displacement in time \(t\) is \(s = ut + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}\). The dimensions of the second term are:

An object moves with \(v = u + at\). If \(u=0\), the x–t relation becomes:
A scooter covers 60 km in 2 h and then 40 km in 1 h on a straight road. Average speed over the trip is:
If \(x = 3t^{2} + 2t\) (m), the instantaneous acceleration is:
For a uniformly accelerated motion, the average velocity in time \(t\) is:
A body moves with piecewise constant velocities: 10 m s^{-1} for 2 s and 20 m s^{-1} for 1 s. Average speed over 3 s is:
In a ticker-tape experiment with constant acceleration, the spacing of successive dots:
A car at x = 0 has \(u=12\,\text{m s}^{-1}\), \(a=-3\,\text{m s}^{-2}\). Time to come to rest is:
With \(u=0\) and constant \(a\), the v–t graph is a straight line through origin. The area under the line from 0 to t equals:
A jogger runs 400 m around a straight 400 m track out-and-back to the start. Average velocity over the trip is:
An object travels with velocity \(v(t) = 4 + 2t\) (m s^{-1}). Displacement in the first 3 s is:
A measurement of time has an uncertainty of \(\pm 0.2\,\text{s}\) over 5.0 s. The percentage uncertainty is:
Two cars A and B move along a straight road with velocities 15 m s^{-1} and 10 m s^{-1} in the same direction. The velocity of A relative to B is:
For \(x = A + Bt + Ct^{2}\), which term contributes to constant acceleration?
A body moves with \(u=8\,\text{m s}^{-1}\) and \(a=2\,\text{m s}^{-2}\). Displacement in 5 s is:
In a lab, you estimate instantaneous velocity using finite differences from x–t data with \(\Delta t=0.05\,\text{s}\). To reduce random error, you should:
options: Differentiate a fitted straight line regardless of curvature
Use central differences over multiple points
moderate.answer: Use central differences over multiple points

moderate.statement: Under constant deceleration, which statement is correct?
A car travels first half of the distance at speed v and the second half at speed 2v. The average speed over the whole distance is:
From \(v^{2} - u^{2} = 2 a s\), the dimension of \(a\) is checked by:
options: Matching \(M L T^{-2}\) on both sides

moderate.statement: A cyclist moves with speed that increases from 6 to 10 m s^{-1} uniformly in 8 s. The displacement in this interval is:
To calibrate a motion sensor for x–t data, the best practice is to:
options: Hold the target by hand while moving
Use a reflective target and measure a known translation
Place it anywhere; distance doesn’t matter
moderate.answer: Use a reflective target and measure a known translation

moderate.statement: A particle’s velocity is given by \(v = 12 - 3t\) (m s^{-1}). The time when it momentarily comes to rest is:
During uniform acceleration experiments, timing with a single hand-held stopwatch mainly introduces:
options: Random error due to human reaction time
No error if repeated trials are done
Systematic error due to zero error only
moderate.answer: Random error due to human reaction time

jee.statement: A car moving with uniform acceleration a passes two points 100 m apart in 5 s. Its speed at the first point is 10 m s^{-1}. The acceleration a is:
Two cars A and B start together from rest. A has constant acceleration 2 m s^{-2} and B has constant acceleration 3 m s^{-2}. The time after which their separation is 50 m is:
A ball is dropped from a height H and rebounds to \(\tfrac{1}{n}\) of its height repeatedly. The total distance covered till it comes to rest is:
A particle moves along x-axis with \(x = 6t^{2} - t^{3}\). The time when it comes momentarily to rest is:
A car moving at 20 m s^{-1} applies brakes producing uniform retardation 4 m s^{-2}. The time and distance needed to stop are respectively:
A particle moves such that its velocity v depends on displacement x as \(v = kx^{1/2}\). The time to move from x = 0 to x = a is:
A car accelerates uniformly from rest for 10 s to reach 30 m s^{-1} and then moves at this speed for another 10 s. The average acceleration for the entire motion is:
A particle moves such that its position is given by \(x = 4t + 3t^{2}\). The ratio of average velocity during 0–2 s to instantaneous velocity at t = 2 s is:
The displacement of a particle is given by x = 10 + 5t + 4t^{2}. The velocity becomes double of its initial value after time:
A rocket moves upward with constant acceleration a. After time t, its engine fails. It continues to move upward for time T before coming to rest. Then:
A bus moving at 20 m s^{-1} is stopped by applying brakes, producing retardation proportional to its speed: a = -0.5v. The stopping distance is:
A ball thrown upward passes a window 10 m above ground at 4 m s^{-1}. Time taken to reach ground after passing the window is:
The velocity of a body moving in a straight line varies as v = 4t - 2t^{2}. The distance covered in first 3 s is:
For a body under uniform acceleration, the ratio of distance covered in the nth second to the (n−1)th second is:
A train moving with uniform acceleration passes a signal post with velocity 20 m s^{-1} and 20 s later passes another with velocity 40 m s^{-1}. The distance between the posts is:
Two bodies start moving along a straight line with velocities 2 m s^{-1} and 4 m s^{-1}. Their accelerations are 2 m s^{-2} and 1 m s^{-2}. The time after which they meet is:
The velocity–time graph of a body is a straight line making an angle of 135° with the time axis. The acceleration is:
A particle moves along a straight line with an acceleration proportional to time t. If it starts from rest, the displacement varies with time as:
A particle covers first half of total time with speed v_1 and second half with v_2. The average speed is:

A ball is thrown vertically upward and passes a point 20 m below its maximum height at speeds 10 m s^{-1} and 10 m s^{-1} upward and downward respectively. The time interval between the two passages is:
A particle starts with velocity u and uniform acceleration a. The distance covered in nth second is:
If the velocity of a body is given by v = k√x, then the acceleration is proportional to:

An experiment measures displacement using ultrasonic sensors and time with a microcontroller clock. The main limitation on velocity accuracy comes from:
